stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on redesigning a sub-area of Course 2, 'Divine Dino Domain,' transforming a boring section into a 'platforming playground.' He discussed future level themes, technical challenges with the game's engine, and his YouTube strategy. A major personal story involved him revealing a bad haircut given by Zeina, which became a running joke.

development_findings.summary: The game is estimated to be just over 80% complete, with only three courses left to finish (13, 14, 15).
development_findings.quote: How much percent finished? Just above 80. We're getting there.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's level design process involves a 'blockout' phase using geometric primitives to establish fun platforming and gameplay flow before committing to detailed 3D modeling and aesthetics.
development_findings.quote: This is the blockout phase. We're kinda blocking out the level here and figuring out how the jump should work. And then after that we're actually 3D modeling this.

development_findings.summary: A significant technical bug exists where water can crash the game because its code hasn't been migrated to a new, mandatory 'step function' system.
development_findings.quote: Water hasn't been updated to the new step function yet and the old step functions are not fully supported anymore, so being in water can just crash the game.

development_findings.summary: Future level themes are planned: Course 13 is a 'mysterious ice castle,' Course 14 is a 'space arcade,' and Course 15's theme is still undecided.
development_findings.quote: We know that course 13 is going to be probably an ice castle like a mysterious type ice castle... And course 14 is going to be a space arcade. But I'm not 100 percent on course 15.

development_findings.summary: A technical limitation of the decompilation project prevents loading level areas individually, consuming significant RAM. Solving this requires learning complex linker scripting, which Kaze has not yet done.
development_findings.quote: The problem is, if you wanted to load the areas one by one, you need to learn a lot of linker script that I haven't learned yet.

development_findings.summary: Course 12 is functionally complete, pending the implementation of a few final animations from Zeina and some signs.
development_findings.quote: I finished Course 12 off-stream, by the way. Mostly. There's a few more animations from Zeina I have to put in the game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is reworking a sub-area in Course 2, 'Divine Dino Domain,' replacing a disliked auto-scrolling section with a more interactive 'platforming playground.'

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed he and Zeina are expecting a child, which will likely prevent him from hosting the F3 event this year and impacts his future schedule.
context_findings.quote: I might not be able to host F3 this year. Because I'm gonna have a child coming out around the same time as F3 would usually be happening. So it's a little tight time-wise for me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze explicitly avoids offering Patreon-exclusive game content to prevent potential legal issues with Nintendo.
context_findings.quote: I don't give out any Patreon bonuses. Because that might get me in legal trouble with Nintendo. So I stay away from that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze candidly discusses the financial reality of his YouTube channels, noting his main channel earned about $450 in the last month and that his total earnings are less than $60,000.
context_findings.quote: YouTube is all about the angle. For 60k a year I'll be your title guy. 60k a year is a lot. I don't think my YouTube channel makes that much. I don't think my YouTube channel made that much in total.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's learning philosophy, particularly for tools like Blender, is to learn by doing and memorizing muscle-memory actions (hotkeys) over formal function names.
context_findings.quote: First of all, you need to learn what you can do in the first place. And while you're doing it, you might as well learn the hotkeys. For example, I don't know what the functions I'm doing do. I don't know what they're called, but I can do them.

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokes about his fear of Nintendo's legal team, preemptively blaming the company if anything were to happen to him.
context_findings.quote: If someone murders me it was a nintendo employee just so you know just so they don't try anything i'm already blaming them for my death.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes a comment on his YouTube video was from a real Nintendo 64 developer, finding the validation meaningful.

biobak.summary: Biobak was active in chat, discussing the impracticality of long hair and agreeing with Kaze's assessment.
Kaze mentions a feature in his editor called "Biobak snapping," which he finds difficult to use, suggesting a tool or feature named after or contributed by Biobak.
biobak.quote: Dude, I hate Biobak snapping. It feels so uncontrollable.

zeina.summary: Zeina accidentally shaved a bald spot on Kaze's head, which became a major running joke and story point throughout the stream.
zeina.quote: Zayna basically took the hair clipper. She took the thing off to clean it. And then she just kept fucking going. Now there's a huge bald line on my head with no hair.

zeina.summary: Zeina has created animations for Course 12 that Kaze still needs to implement into the game.
Kaze and Zeina's personal dynamic was highlighted when he stated he wouldn't let her have short hair, acknowledging his double standard.
zeina.quote: Would I let Zeina go bald? No, that would look awful. But that's double standards case. Yeah, so what? Cry about it.

key_stories.title: The Haircut Incident
key_stories.summary: Zeina's haircut mishap became a central narrative of the stream. Kaze's attempt to hide it with a beanie led to a viewer-driven 'reveal' that showcased his humor, his relationship with his audience, and his dynamic with Zeina.
key_stories.challenge: Zeina accidentally shaved a bald line into Kaze's hair while giving him a haircut.
key_stories.process: Kaze started the stream wearing a beanie to hide his hair. Viewers became curious, so he created an impromptu deal where he would reveal more of his hair with each new subscription. After a flurry of subs, he fully revealed the haircut.
key_stories.outcome: After pressure and subscription incentives from his viewers, Kaze revealed the haircut. This led to a humorous segment discussing his appearance, personal grooming preferences, and his relationship dynamic with Zeina.
key_stories.key_quote: Okay, here you go. My fucked up haircut. You see that? There's just the fucking bald line here.

key_stories.title: YouTube Title Optimization
key_stories.summary: Kaze noticed a new video was failing to attract viewers and decided to change its title live on stream. He swapped a descriptive title for a sensationalist one, explaining that the 'angle' is more important than accuracy for YouTube success.
key_stories.challenge: A newly uploaded YouTube video was underperforming with a low click-through rate of only 7.4%.
key_stories.process: Kaze checked his YouTube analytics live on stream and noted the poor performance. He brainstormed with his chat for a more 'clickable' title, settling on a provocative one that creates intrigue regardless of the video's actual content.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze changed the title to the highly sensational 'Nintendo's Biggest Lie,' confident it would dramatically improve the video's performance. This demonstrated his practical, if cynical, approach to YouTube marketing.
key_stories.key_quote: Nintendo's biggest lie. Oh my god. That's fucking insane. Oh, oh shit. This is an insane title. Watch this go to like 20% critical rate.

key_stories.title: Reworking a 'Sucky' Level Section
key_stories.summary: Kaze decided an old section of a level wasn't fun and spent the stream completely reworking it. He demonstrated his design philosophy of prioritizing gameplay flow and fun by building a 'blockout' of a new platforming area from scratch.
key_stories.challenge: A sub-area in Course 2, which used 'leaf bolts' for a semi-autoscrolling section, was deemed boring and unfun to play.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified the core problem with the old design. He then spent the stream in a 'blockout' phase, using simple geometric shapes to build and test new platforming paths, ensuring the layout was fun before adding any aesthetic details.
key_stories.outcome: The section was redesigned into a 'platforming playground' with varied elements like moving platforms, spiral staircases, and planned vine sections. The focus shifted entirely from passive travel to active, engaging platforming.
key_stories.key_quote: I realized the section sucked. So now we have a little bit of a platforming playground here.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he is expecting a child with Zeina around the time he would normally host F3, a major community event.
questions: Congratulations! How is this incredible life change affecting your development schedule and your long-term vision for the project?
How do you and Zeina plan to balance the demands of a newborn with finishing a massive creative endeavor like this?
Has becoming a father changed your perspective on game design or the kinds of experiences you want to create?

open_questions.topic: The 'New Step Function' and Technical Architecture
open_questions.context: Kaze stated that a critical bug causing game crashes in water is due to the water code not being updated to a 'new step function.'
questions: Can you explain what the 'new step function' is and why it was necessary to implement?
What was the process of creating this new system and migrating the game's code over to it?
What are the biggest technical hurdles you've had to overcome by building on the decompilation project instead of a traditional ROM hack?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Course 14 will be a 'space arcade' and that he's secretly worked on a part of it he can't show due to a 'compact.'
questions: What is the core concept behind the 'space arcade' theme?
What kind of gameplay can we expect from this level?
What was the 'compact' you mentioned? Was this an agreement with other creators or a personal goal for a reveal?

open_questions.topic: Designing the Final Levels and Bosses
open_questions.context: Kaze is undecided on a theme for Course 15 and asked his stream chat for ideas for a boss for the Course 13 Ice Castle.
questions: What are your current thoughts or initial ideas for Course 15?
What makes a good final level in your design philosophy?
Regarding the Ice Castle boss, what are the key ingredients for a memorable boss fight in this game? What have you learned from designing previous bosses?

open_questions.context: Kaze explained that the decompilation project forces all levels to be loaded into RAM at once, and fixing it requires learning 'linker script.'
questions: Have you made any progress on learning linker scripts to solve the RAM issue?
How does this RAM limitation affect your level design? Do you have to build smaller or less complex areas than you'd like?
Who on the team, if anyone, helps with these deep, engine-level technical challenges?
